name: solanum-carolinense
country-or-region-of-origin: East Canada to Northern Mexico and Haiti
distribution: Native: Canada--Ontario and Quebec; Haiti; Mexico--Northeast and Northwest;  United States--AL
wildlife-value: Bumblebees and insects are attracted to the flowers. The mature yellow fruits may be eaten by quail, wild turkey, and some small mammals.
edibility: All parts of this plant are poisonous to humans.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: The fruit is a round, green berry and becomes yellow and wrinkled when ripened. The berry is about 1/2 inches in diameter. Each berry contains many seeds. The fruits ripen in the fall and may persist through the winter.
flower-description: The flowers may be solitary or occur in clusters. Each flower is star-shaped with five white to light violet petals. The petals curve downward, and there are protruding yellow stamens in the center.
leaf-description: The leaves are alternate, oblong to ovate, and is covered on both sides with star-shaped hairs. The leaf measures 2 to 6 inches long, up to 3 inches wide, and is irregularly lobed. The leaf edges are frequently wavy. There is the odor of a potato when the leaves are crushed or bruised.
stem-description: The stems are green, upright, and may be branched or unbranched. They have sharp prickles and star-shaped hairs.  The stem forms a zig-zag pattern. They are angled at the nodes and become woody with age. The petioles have yellow prickles.
poison-symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, drowsiness, abdominal pain, diarrhea, weakness, respiratory depression; coma, may be fatal.
uses: Carolina horse nettle was used by Native Americans and the early settlers. It was listed in the National Formulary from 1916 to 1936. It has been used for medicinal purposes such as treating poison ivy, epilepsy, asthma, bronchitis, and tetanus.
